title: I play the clarinet, and I tongue pretty heavily. Sometimes you can hear the faintest bit of a thu sound. What can I do to fix this? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, that’s a common problem. If you want somewhere to start with, you can start practicing tonguing without the clarinet in your mouth. Try to make your tongue light as it touches the reed. If you can still hear the “thu” sound even after practicing that, the best advice I’ve got is this: The tip of the tongue to the tip of the reed. As I learned it, only one taste bud should touch the reed. This may sound a little weird, but take your fingernail, hold it vertically, and scratch the middle part of your tongue, so that the sensation on that taste bud can help you to know what part of the tongue to put on the reed. Also, another reason might be that your tongue is low inside your mouth, so try keeping your tongue up, and again, touching only the tip of your reed. I hope that this can help you!

I suggest put far less in your mouth….also, hold it more vertical, just off the chin. may be you are putting tonge too far forward, and too enthusiastically. Tonge gently, but quickly. my teacher, from the TSO, said I tongue like a snake. My staccato is nearly awesome. hope this helps….
